SENT.plain: PURPOSE: To report a case of pseudotumor cerebri (PTC) following treatment with human recombinant growth hormone (GH)
METHODS: A 42-year-old man who developed pseudotumor cerebri 7 years after starting human recombinant GH treatment is presented
RESULTS: The patient's medical history was significant for hypophyseal dwarfism with a serious deficit of GH, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, and hypothyroidism
In 1996 he started taking GH, testosterone, and L-thyroxine
Fundus examination showed disc edema in the left eye
GH was discontinued, and acetazolamide therapy was initiated
At the 3-month follow-up the acuity without correction was patch and the unilateral papilledema had resolved
CONCLUSIONS: Pseudotumor cerebri or idiopathic intracranial hypertension is an uncommon and complex disorder
The diagnosis is possible when important criteria symptoms and signs are met
Several conditions and risk factors are associated with PTC
The most recently recognized risk factor is GH therapy
